attributes.title: A Re-Examination of the Sexual Opinion Survey - Pilot

q1.value: A Re-Examination of the Sexual Opinion Survey - Pilot

q2.value: Nazanin Kafaee, Taylor Kohut, Samantha Joel

q4.value: Although the purpose of this study is somewhat exploratory, we do expect to see correlations between affective responses to sexual cues and erotophilia/erotophobia captured by the old SOS items, as well as the other sexuality-reality constructs (e.g., Sociosexuality, Sexual Compulsivity, etc.). We also expect to find moderate to strong positive correlations between measures like Sociosexulity and the SOS items. Further, new SOS items which reflect sexual behaviors that were not covered on the original SOS are expected to add incremental validity when combined with the original SOS items.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: This is a cross-sectional validation study. The focus of the study is assessing the criterion validity by examining associations between the original and new SOS items and the affective responses following exposure to 22 examples of sexual media.

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

question.value:
Participants will be recruited through social media platforms (e.g. Instagram, Reddit, Facebook, etc.) and Western University’s research participation pool . Participants from the social media platforms will be invited to participate in the study by completing the online survey for the chance of winning a $100 gift card; while undergraduate students from the university's research participation pool will be granted 0.5 credit for their participation. 
Individuals interested in joining the study must be at least 18 years of age, be able to read and respond to questions posed in English, and reside in Canada or the US.
Recruitment will be taking place between February 2020 - May 2020.

q13.value: Our target sample size was set as 500 from both social media and university research pool. We will attempt to have up to 350 complete responses.

question.value:
The outcome variable will be the emotional responses to the 13-item Feelings scale that is asked for the second time after exposure to the sexual media (e.g. “Right now I feel: Sexually aroused”). 
With the exception of the social desirability, demographic, and sexual arousal items, all items from all the scales employed in this study (148 in total) will be considered as candidate predictors of the residualized responses to the sexual media. 
Measures Used in the Study:
SOS items (original and new): The original 21-item SOS (Fisher et al., 1988) (e.g. Masturbation can be an exciting experience.) and the new 58-item SOS (current authors) (e.g. 4.	Receiving sexually suggestive texts and images from my boyfriend/girlfriend is very sexy.).
Sexual Arousal: A single item measure (e.g. “How arousing do you find the above picture?”).
Feelings Scale:13-item Feelings scale (Smeaton, & Byrne, 1998, p. 50) (e.g. “Right now I feel: Sexually aroused”).
Social Desirability: 10-item Social desirability scale (Strahan, Gerbasi, 1973) (e.g. “I never resent being asked to return a favor”).
Revised Sociosexuality Inventory: 9-item Revised Sociosexuality Inventory (Penke & Asendorpf, 2008) (e.g. “Sex without love is OK.”).
Sexual Compulsivity Scale: 10-item Sexual Compulsivity Scale (Kalichman & Rompa, 2001) (e.g. “My sexual appetite has gotten in the way of my relationships”).
Double Standard Scale: 10-item Double Standard Scale (Caron, Davis, Halteman, Stickle, 1993) (e.g. “It is expected that a woman be less sexually experienced than her partner.”).
Sexual Health Survey: 4-item Sexual Health Survey (Eastman-Muller, Carr & Osterlind, 2006) will be assessed using of its knowledge subscale (e.g. “Women can become pregnant the first time they engage in vaginal-penile intercourse.”).
Measure of Sexual Identity Exploration and Commitment (Worthington, Navarro, Savoy & Hampton, 2008) will be captured using 6 items of the commitment subscale (e.g. “I know what my preferences are for expressing myself sexually.”) and 2 items sexual orientation (e.g. “My sexual orientation is clear to me.”). 
Brief Sensation Seeking Scale: 8-item Brief Sensation Seeking Scale (Hoyle, Stephenson, Palmgreen, Lorch, & Donohew, 2001) (e.g. “I prefer friends who are excitingly unpredictable.”). 
Religiosity: 3-item Religiosity scale (Hill & Hood,1999) (e.g. “How often do you attend religious services and activities?”).
Conservatism: 7-item Conservatism scale (Henningham, 1996) (e.g. agreeing or disagreeing with “Multiculturalism”). All the items that had sexual connotations (e.g. “Gay rights”) were removed from this scale.

To re-examine the validity of the SOS, we will be using a method of machine learning called random forest. This method has some advantages over the traditional regression models, including sensitivity to non-linear relationships, and testing for a wide range of predictors simultaneously while minimizing overfitting (Strobl, Malley, & Tutz, 2009; Liaw & Wiener, 2015; Joel, Eastwick & Finkel, 2017).

To control for social desirability, affective responses will first be regressed on social desirability. The residuals of this analysis will then be used as the outcome in the random forest model. Afterwards, with the exception of the social desirability, demographic, and sexual arousal items, all items from all the scales employed in this study (148 in total) will be considered as candidate predictors of the residualized responses to the sexual media.

The data cleaning, and regression analysis will be conducted in SPSS. We will then be using the VSURF (Variable Selection Using Random Forest) package for R to reduce the candidate predictor variables to a subset of variables that will be used in the final analysis. VSURF operates in three steps: 1) the threshold step, which removes variables that are not related to the outcome; 2) the moderate or interpretation step, which identifies all variables that are important for predicting the response variable (with some redundancy); and 3) the prediction step, which reduces the number of predictors further to lower redundancy in the predictors (Genuer, Poggi, & Tuleau-Malot, 2015).The predictors recommended by the interpretation step will be used to run the final random forest model. Total amount of variance predicted, the mean squared error, and the specific variables that emerged as predictors in their order of strength will then be reported and interpreted (Joel, Eastwick & Finkel, 2017).

To address all three goals of this study, we will retain original and new SOS items for further scrutiny if at least some of them are found to be among the best-predicting items for further scale validation. If all the best predicting items are not from these two sources, it would suggest that the SOS scale does not do what it is intended to do.

Provided that the predictive utility of the original and new SOS items is confirmed, we will conduct an exploratory factor analysis (EFA; maximum likelihood, parallel analysis + interpretability to identify the number of extracted factors; direct oblimin rotation to improve interpretation) on all of old and new SOS items that emerge from the interpretation step of VSURF procedure to examine construct validity. The goals of this EFA will be to: (1) clarify the underlying factor structure of these SOS items; (2) reduce the item pool by retaining only the 5 most highly loading items who’s pattern coefficients exceed .40 for each factor (high cross-loadings will not be used to disqualify items), and (3) identify interpretable factors that are poorly represented by the current item set (factors that are represented by fewer than 5 items that have pattern coefficients >.40). The results of this effort will then be used to guide a confirmatory factor analysis to determine the extent that such a model fits the data using typical cutoffs for fit indices. Additional conceptual dimensions may be identified at this stage if error covariances are needed to ensure acceptable model fit. If needed, a subsequent study may be conducted to validate additional items that may be needed to fill out poorly represented dimensions. If no additional items are needed, subsequent work will seek to confirm the factor structure by replicating the CFA model tested in the current study, establish evidence of convergent / divergent validity of the revised SOS scale and each of its sub-dimensions, and examine measurement invariance to determine the revised SOS represents and assesses the same concept across various groups (e.g. gender, sexual orientation).

attributes.title: Acetaminophen & Morality
attributes.description: This project is investigating how the drug acetaminophen (the active ingredient in Tylenol) affects moral judgments

q1.value: The effects of acetaminophen on moral judgment and decision-making

q2.value: Jordan Wylie, Hanah Chapman, Matthew Vanaman, Justin Storbeck

q3.value:
Debates concerning the active ingredient in moral judgment and decision-making continue to burden the field of moral psychology. The primary aim of the present research is to help adjudicate arguments that pit emotivist-intuitionist views (e.g., Haidt, 2001) against more cognitive views (e.g., Kohlberg, 1971; Royzman, Goodwin, & Leeman, 2011). 

The “amplification hypothesis”, which suggests incidental emotions intensify moral judgments, has emerged as critical to the ongoing debate (Pizarro, Inbar, and Helion, 2011; Landy & Goodwin, 2016). However, experimental evidence has been limited and subject to confounds. 

To address this, we will utilize a novel pharmacological approach (acetaminophen) to investigate whether emotion plays a pivotal role in judgments of moral condemnation. We will also investigate whether the influence of emotion on moral condemnation interacts with the domain of the moral transgression. 

A second aim of this experiment is to examine the effects of acetaminophen intervention on moral decision making. We will test whether acetaminophen, by influencing emotional breadth, reduces likelihood of choosing deontological options. Further, we will also replicate previous research and examine whether acetaminophen decreases empathic concern (Mischkowski et al., 2016), thus increasing likelihood of utilitarian decision making.

q4.value:
Hypotheses - Moral Transgressions

DV: Immorality 

Research Question 1: Does acetaminophen reduce condemnation of moral transgressions?
H1a (Emotivist Hypothesis): Immorality ratings will be lower for the acetaminophen condition than the placebo condition in the harm and/or purity conditions.
H1b (Cognitivist Hypothesis): Immorality ratings will not differ significantly between the treatment conditions. 

Research Question 2: Does Mindfulness moderate the relationship between Treatment and immorality ratings for Purity and/or Harm Transgressions?
H3 (Schnall et al (2015) hypothesis): Treatment will have a weaker effect on moral judgments for those higher in Mindfulness than those lower in Mindfulness 

*Note that either a main effect of Treatment on Immorality (RQ1, Hypothesis 1a) or significant moderation by Mindfulness (RQ3, Schnall hypothesis) would support emotivist models of moral judgment  

Research Question 3 (Exploratory): Does Treatment have a different effect on immorality ratings for the Purity and Harm Transgression conditions?

DV: Emotion

Research Question 4: Does acetaminophen reduce ratings of emotion?
H5: Emotion ratings will be lower for the acetaminophen condition than the placebo condition in the harm and/or purity conditions.

Research Question 5 (Exploratory): Does Treatment have a different effect on Emotion ratings for the Purity and Harm Transgression conditions?

Hypotheses - Moral Dilemmas

DV: U (preference for utilitarianism) and D (preference for deontology) process-dissociation scores.

Research Question 6: Does acetaminophen reduce preference for deontological decision making? 
H6a(Emotivist Hypothesis): Preference for deontology will be lower for the acetaminophen condition than the placebo condition in the harm and/or purity conditions.
H6b(Cognitivist Hypothesis): Preference for deontology  will not differ significantly between the treatment conditions. 

Research Question 7: Does acetaminophen increase preference for utilitarian decision making? 
H7a(Emotivist Hypothesis): Preference for utilitarianism will be higher for the acetaminophen condition than the placebo condition in the harm and/or purity conditions.
H7b(Cognitivist Hypothesis): Preference for utilitarianism will not differ significantly between the treatment conditions. 

Moderation and Mediation

Research Question 8: Does Mindfulness Mediation moderate the relationship between Treatment and immorality ratings for Purity and Harm Transgressions? 
H8: Mindfulness Mediation will moderate the relationship between Treatment and Immorality ratings.

Research Question 9: Does Emotion mediate the relationship between Treatment and Condemnation?
H9a: Emotivist Hypothesis: Emotion will mediate the relationship between Treatment and Condemnation.
H9b: Cognitivist Hypothesis: Emotion will not mediate the relationship between Treatment and Condemnation

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: Personnel who analyze the data collected from the study are not aware of the treatment applied to any given group.
Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)
For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value:
Moral Transgressions: 
A counterbalanced 2 (Treatment; Acetaminophen or Placebo) x 3 (Transgression Type: Harm, Purity, and Social Conventional) mixed factorial design.
Within-subjects IV: Transgression Type 
Between-subjects IV: Treatment - participants will be randomly assigned to either Acetaminophen or Placebo conditions.   

Moral Dilemmas (will always follow moral transgression ratings): 
A counterbalanced 2 (Treatment; Acetaminophen or Placebo) x 2 (Dilemma Type: Utilitarian vs. Deontological) mixed factorial design.
Within-subjects IV: Dilemma Type 
Between-subjects IV: Treatment

q9.value: Treatment condition will be randomly assigned. Only an experimenter who will not interact with participants, data collection or analyses will keep track of the treatment versus placebo administration.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Participants 
Queens college students will be recruited from campus and the subject pool for participation. Participants will be compensated for participation. Participants will be recruited over the Fall and Spring semesters. 

Data exclusion 	
Participants will be excluded from study protocol and analyses if they have never previously taken acetaminophen, or if they have taken acetaminophen the same day as signing up for the experiment. 

Data inclusion 
Participants will only be included if they are over 18 years of age. 

Missing data
Due to IRB requirements, subjects will be free to skip any question they choose. For each subject, any scale with more than 25% missing items will be excluded from the analysis. Scores for missing items below that threshold will be interpolated using the mean response to the other items on that scale or subscale.

q13.value: A minimum of 130 participants per cell (260 total) will be recruited.

q14.value: Based on previous acetaminophen studies, treatment effect sizes range from d=.35 to d=.55 (Durso et al., 2015; Mischikowski et al., 2016) dependent upon the type of judgment made. To power the main treatment effect, we used the conservative d=.35. For a d=.35 and 80% power, 130 subjects per cell (260 total) are required (PANGEA; Westfall, 2016).

q15.value: We will continue collecting data until 260 participants are collected or to the conclusion of the semester during which data is currently being collected. Recruitment may exceed 130 in order to collect data through the end of a given semester; however, we will not check data prior to whichever requirement is last achieved (either 260 or end of semester).

question.value:
To investigate the influence of acetaminophen on moral judgments and decision-making, we will use a double-blind placebo randomized controlled trial. The only variable subject to random assignment will be the treatment condition.

Treatment Condition:
Acetaminophen condition
Placebo condition

How we will randomize:
Participants will be randomly assigned to each treatment condition using block randomization. That is, we will achieve balanced groups by creating a list containing equal numbers of acetaminophen and placebo assignments (130 each). We will randomize the list, treat the first element of the list as the assignment for the first participant, then assign participants as they arrive while moving down the list.

Measured Variables 

DVs -----
Moral Transgression DVs:

Judgment of moral condemnation: “How morally wrong do you think this action is? 
from 1 to 7; (Not at all wrong to Extremely wrong)

Judgment of emotion: “How negative does this action make you feel?
from 1 to 7; (Not at all negative to Extremely negative)

Preference for Utilitarianism/Deontology:
We will create U (preference for utilitarianism) and D (preference for deontology) parameters using the method outlined in Conway and Gawronski (2013)*. See Indices section for more information.

IVs:

Individual Differences:
Three Domain Disgust Scale (TDDS)
Baer Five Facets of Mindfulness Scale 
Toronto Empathy Questionnaire
Big Five Aspects Scale (N)
Moral Foundation Questionnaire (MFQ)
Condition Guess
Recent food intake

Moral Transgression Type:
- 10 Purity Domain Transgressions from Clifford et al., 2015
- 10 Harm Domain Transgressions from Clifford et al., 2015
- 10 Social Norm Violations from Clifford et al., 2015
- Presentation of Transgression Type: random sampling without replacement.
- Note: Harm and Purity transgressions are matched on arousal and wrongness (Arousal: Mharm=4.3, Mpurity =4.2; Wrongness: Mharm=3.8, Mpurity =3.6; t’s less than 1.63, p’s greater than.12)

Moral Dilemmas:
We will use the congruent and incongruent moral dilemmas developed by Conway and Gawronski (2013)*. Because of time constraints,  we chose the six shortest dilemmas, each of which contains a congruent and incongruent version. Dilemmas will be presented in random order without repetition (random sample without replacement). The dilemmas are listed in the attachment below. 

*Conway, P. & Gawronski, B. (2013). Deontological and utilitarian inclinations in moral decision making: a process dissociation approach. Journal of personality and social psychology, 104(2), 216. Chicago

All individual difference scales:
We will score scales according to the instructions provided by the original authors. For scales for which no instructions have been published, we take the arithmetic mean. To assess scale reliability, we will report Cronbach’s alphas and flag any alphas less than 0.6 as a limitation of measurement.
D and U Indices:
Each dilemma ends by asking if it is appropriate to do the action described at the end of the dilemma (Yes or No). The U and D indices thus represent conditional probabilities, which will be derived from participants' choices of Yes vs No to the appropriateness questions at the end of each dilemma. 
To calculate the D and U indices for each participant using the process dissociation approach described in Conway and Gawronski (2013), we will use the following formulas: 
Preference for Utilitarianism: U =􏰁 p(􏰋unacceptable 􏰈| congruent) -􏰌 p(􏰋unacceptable | incongruent􏰌)
Preference for Deontology: D =􏰁 p(􏰋unacceptable 􏰈| incongruent) / (1 - U)
For more information, see pages 219 - 220 of the attached article.

Research Questions and Analysis Plan 

Awareness of treatment condition:

A chi-squared test will be used to determine whether participants were able to guess their treatment condition at above-chance levels. If there are any expected values less than 5, we will use fisher's exact test.

If the chi squared test is significant (indicating better than chance awareness of condition), perceived treatment condition will be included as a covariate in all analyses  

Moral Transgressions: 

DV: Immorality 

RQ1: Does acetaminophen reduce condemnation of moral transgressions?
RQ4: (Exploratory): Does Treatment have a different effect on immorality ratings for the Purity and Harm Transgression conditions?

Analysis for RQ1 and RQ4: We will employ a mixed effects multivariable linear regression model with Immorality as the DV and the following Fixed Effects as predictors: 

Treatment Condition (1= acetaminophen, 0 = placebo)
Transgresion Type (purity, harm, with non-moral as the reference level) 
Interaction terms: Treatment * Transgression type

As well as the following Random Effects:
Participant
Stimuli

We will start with a maximal model that includes random slopes and correlated random intercepts for both Participants and Stimuli. If the maximal model does not converge, we will use the most complex specification that our data allow.

We will conduct a likelihood ratio test between this model and a model that includes the counterbalanced order of MFQ and Disgust index as a predictor. If this test is significant, we will include order in the model to control for these order effects. This will comprise the final model.

RQ2: Does Mindfulness moderate the relationship between Treatment and immorality ratings for Purity and/or Harm Transgressions?

Analysis: Separate mixed effects multivariable linear regressions will be conducted for the Harm and Purity transgressions. Immorality as the DV and the following Fixed Effects as predictors: 

Treatment Condition (1= acetaminophen, 0 = placebo)
Mindfulness
Interaction term: Treatment * Mindfulness

As well as the following Random Effects:
Participant
Stimulus

We will start with a maximal model that includes random slopes and correlated random intercepts for both Participants and Stimuli. If the maximal model does not converge, we will use the most complex specification that our data allow.

DV: Emotion

RQ5: Does acetaminophen reduce ratings of emotion?
RQ6 (Exploratory): Does Treatment have a different effect on Emotion ratings for the Purity and Harm Transgression conditions?

Analysis for RQs 5 and 6: We will employ a mixed effects multivariable linear regression model with Emotion as the DV and the following Fixed Effects as predictors: 

Treatment Condition (1= acetaminophen, 0 = placebo)
Transgresion Type (purity, harm, with non-moral as the reference level) 
Interaction terms: Treatment * Transgression Type

As well as the following Random Effects:
Participant
Stimuli

We will start with a maximal model that includes random slopes and correlated random intercepts for both Participants and Stimuli. If the maximal model does not converge,  we will use the most complex specification that our data allow.

We will conduct a likelihood ratio test between this model and a model that includes the counterbalanced order of MFQ and Disgust index as a predictor. If this test is significant, we will include order in the model to control for order effects. This will comprise the final model.

DV: Preference for Utilitarianism/Deontology 

RQ7a/b: Does Treatment condition affect preference for deontology (a) or utilitarianism (b)?

Analysis: We will conduct 2 mixed effects multivariable linear regression models, one with preference for deontology (D parameter) as the DV, and the other with preference for utilitarianism (U parameter) as the DV. Both models will contain the following:

Fixed Effects as predictors: 
Treatment Condition (1= acetaminophen, 0 = placebo)

As well as the following Random Effects:
Participant
Stimuli

We will start with a maximal model that includes random slopes and correlated random intercepts for both Participants and Stimuli. If the maximal model does not converge,  we will use the most complex specification that our data allow.


Moderation and Mediation

RQ8: Does Mindfulness Mediation moderate the relationship between Treatment and immorality ratings for Purity and Harm Transgressions?

Analysis: We will employ a mixed effects multivariable linear regression model with Emotionality as the DV and the following 

Fixed Effects as predictors: 
Treatment Condition (1= acetaminophen, 0 = placebo)
Mindfulness Mediation 
Interaction term: Treatment Condition * Mindfulness Mediation 

As well as the following Random Effects:
Participant
Stimuli

We will start with a maximal model that includes random slopes and correlated random intercepts for both Participants and Stimuli. If the maximal model does not converge,  we will use the most complex specification that our data allow.

RQ9 Does Emotion mediate the relationship between Treatment and Condemnation?

Analysis: We will conduct a mediation with Treatment as the IV, Immorality as the DV, Emotion as the mediator

q21.value:
Inference criteria 	 	 								

We will use the standard p less than or equal to 0.05 criteria for determining if the predictors in our regressions and are significantly different from those that would be expected if the null hypothesis were true. All analyses will be two-tailed. Variance inflation factors will be examined in all multiple regressions. VIFs > 10 will be flagged as problematic. In this case, we will explore alternative analyses that can accommodate correlated predictors (e.g. path analysis).

q22.value: Participants will be excluded from study protocol and analyses if they have never  previously taken acetaminophen, or if they have taken acetaminophen the same day as signing up for the experiment. Additionally, participants will only be included if they are over 18 years of age.

q25.value:
Additional background context:

Acetaminophen and moral condemnation. We will investigate the influence of emotion on moral condemnation by manipulating emotion with acetaminophen. Acetaminophen, or Tylenol as it is commonly known, is an analgesic that has been shown to reduce the extremity of emotion evaluations for both positive and negative valence, but not non-evaluative judgments (Durso et al., 2015). Using a double-blind placebo controlled design, we will first administer treatment, and then collect judgments of normed transgressions (Clifford et al., 2015) that are matched on arousal (moderate-high arousal) and wrongness (moderately-highly wrong), and decisions on moral dilemmas that include personal and impersonal dilemmas. We have selected transgressions from the harm and purity domains, and included social norm violations from the same battery (Clifford et al., 2015) to act as a neutral control. Unlike the moral transgressions (harm and purity), social norm violations are already near floor for wrongness and emotion; thus, we don’t expect Tylenol to further reduce ratings, but instead have included them to provide contrast to the moral violations. The present study will also investigate whether acetaminophen differentially affects condemnation of purity transgressions, harm transgressions, or violations of social norms. 

Acetaminophen and emotion. Given the importance of the role of emotion in the present research, we will collect emotion ratings for each moral judgment or dilemma. These ratings will be used to assess whether acetaminophen has reduced the overall average ratings of emotion. Critically, we will also test emotion as a mediating variable in the relationship between acetaminophen and moral judgments or decisions. Indeed, if ratings of emotion do not mediate the relationship between treatment and moral judgment, this would provide strong evidence against the self-perception of emotion driving moral judgments. Of course, acetaminophen may affect emotion in ways that are not captured by our measure (e.g., physiology), but this outcome would be most consistent with cognitivist views of moral judgment.

Moderation of treatment effects by individual differences. Previous research has suggested that individuals high in personal body awareness evidence larger effects of emotion manipulations on moral judgment (Schnall et al., 2008). We will therefore investigate whether personal body awareness and trait mindfulness moderate the effect of acetaminophen on moral judgment. 

Experimental Procedure

Following the informed consent process, participants will be randomly assigned to either acetaminophen condition or placebo condition. This will begin the treatment uptake period (60 minutes), during which participants will complete a number of questionnaires that do not contain either moral, emotional, or related construct questions (e.g., Big Five Aspects; Duke Religion Index, Paranormal Beliefs). Participants will work on these questionnaires for 60 minutes or until they finish. If they finish before the end of the uptake period, they will complete puzzles (e.g., Sudoku) until the minimum uptake period has passed. 

After the uptake period is complete, participants will begin the main experimental task. They will first assess transgressions; each transgression type will be in a separate block, with the scenarios presented in random order. To minimize the likelihood of participants being swayed by their own ratings, we have split the moral and emotion ratings. Participants will view each scenario twice for a single block (before moving to the next block): first, randomly presented scenarios from the block will be followed by the immorality rating; second, the same scenarios will be presented randomly again and followed by the emotion rating. The order of transgression block presentation will be counterbalanced across participants. Following this, participants will view and make judgments about 10 personal and 10 impersonal dilemmas presented in fully-randomized trials. The block of 20 dilemmas will always follow the blocks of transgressions.  

Participants will then complete the key individual differences measures (e.g., MFQ). Finally, when the participant completes the main experimental procedure, the experimenter will administer a condition guess questionnaire to assess whether participants were accurately able to guess the treatment they were randomly assigned to.

registration_responses.q1: The effects of acetaminophen on moral judgment and decision-making
registration_responses.q2: Jordan Wylie, Hanah Chapman, Matthew Vanaman, Justin Storbeck
registration_responses.q3:
Debates concerning the active ingredient in moral judgment and decision-making continue to burden the field of moral psychology. The primary aim of the present research is to help adjudicate arguments that pit emotivist-intuitionist views (e.g., Haidt, 2001) against more cognitive views (e.g., Kohlberg, 1971; Royzman, Goodwin, & Leeman, 2011). 

The “amplification hypothesis”, which suggests incidental emotions intensify moral judgments, has emerged as critical to the ongoing debate (Pizarro, Inbar, and Helion, 2011; Landy & Goodwin, 2016). However, experimental evidence has been limited and subject to confounds. 

To address this, we will utilize a novel pharmacological approach (acetaminophen) to investigate whether emotion plays a pivotal role in judgments of moral condemnation. We will also investigate whether the influence of emotion on moral condemnation interacts with the domain of the moral transgression. 

A second aim of this experiment is to examine the effects of acetaminophen intervention on moral decision making. We will test whether acetaminophen, by influencing emotional breadth, reduces likelihood of choosing deontological options. Further, we will also replicate previous research and examine whether acetaminophen decreases empathic concern (Mischkowski et al., 2016), thus increasing likelihood of utilitarian decision making.
registration_responses.q4:
Hypotheses - Moral Transgressions

DV: Immorality 

Research Question 1: Does acetaminophen reduce condemnation of moral transgressions?
H1a (Emotivist Hypothesis): Immorality ratings will be lower for the acetaminophen condition than the placebo condition in the harm and/or purity conditions.
H1b (Cognitivist Hypothesis): Immorality ratings will not differ significantly between the treatment conditions. 

Research Question 2: Does Mindfulness moderate the relationship between Treatment and immorality ratings for Purity and/or Harm Transgressions?
H3 (Schnall et al (2015) hypothesis): Treatment will have a weaker effect on moral judgments for those higher in Mindfulness than those lower in Mindfulness 

*Note that either a main effect of Treatment on Immorality (RQ1, Hypothesis 1a) or significant moderation by Mindfulness (RQ3, Schnall hypothesis) would support emotivist models of moral judgment  

Research Question 3 (Exploratory): Does Treatment have a different effect on immorality ratings for the Purity and Harm Transgression conditions?

DV: Emotion

Research Question 4: Does acetaminophen reduce ratings of emotion?
H5: Emotion ratings will be lower for the acetaminophen condition than the placebo condition in the harm and/or purity conditions.

Research Question 5 (Exploratory): Does Treatment have a different effect on Emotion ratings for the Purity and Harm Transgression conditions?

Hypotheses - Moral Dilemmas

DV: U (preference for utilitarianism) and D (preference for deontology) process-dissociation scores.

Research Question 6: Does acetaminophen reduce preference for deontological decision making? 
H6a(Emotivist Hypothesis): Preference for deontology will be lower for the acetaminophen condition than the placebo condition in the harm and/or purity conditions.
H6b(Cognitivist Hypothesis): Preference for deontology  will not differ significantly between the treatment conditions. 

Research Question 7: Does acetaminophen increase preference for utilitarian decision making? 
H7a(Emotivist Hypothesis): Preference for utilitarianism will be higher for the acetaminophen condition than the placebo condition in the harm and/or purity conditions.
H7b(Cognitivist Hypothesis): Preference for utilitarianism will not differ significantly between the treatment conditions. 

Moderation and Mediation

Research Question 8: Does Mindfulness Mediation moderate the relationship between Treatment and immorality ratings for Purity and Harm Transgressions? 
H8: Mindfulness Mediation will moderate the relationship between Treatment and Immorality ratings.

Research Question 9: Does Emotion mediate the relationship between Treatment and Condemnation?
H9a: Emotivist Hypothesis: Emotion will mediate the relationship between Treatment and Condemnation.
H9b: Cognitivist Hypothesis: Emotion will not mediate the relationship between Treatment and Condemnation

Inference criteria 	 	 								

We will use the standard p less than or equal to 0.05 criteria for determining if the predictors in our regressions and are significantly different from those that would be expected if the null hypothesis were true. All analyses will be two-tailed. Variance inflation factors will be examined in all multiple regressions. VIFs > 10 will be flagged as problematic. In this case, we will explore alternative analyses that can accommodate correlated predictors (e.g. path analysis).

registration_responses.q12.question:
Participants 
Queens college students will be recruited from campus and the subject pool for participation. Participants will be compensated for participation. Participants will be recruited over the Fall and Spring semesters. 

Data exclusion 	
Participants will be excluded from study protocol and analyses if they have never previously taken acetaminophen, or if they have taken acetaminophen the same day as signing up for the experiment. 

Data inclusion 
Participants will only be included if they are over 18 years of age. 

Missing data
Due to IRB requirements, subjects will be free to skip any question they choose. For each subject, any scale with more than 25% missing items will be excluded from the analysis. Scores for missing items below that threshold will be interpolated using the mean response to the other items on that scale or subscale.
registration_responses.q16.question:
To investigate the influence of acetaminophen on moral judgments and decision-making, we will use a double-blind placebo randomized controlled trial. The only variable subject to random assignment will be the treatment condition.

Treatment Condition:
Acetaminophen condition
Placebo condition

How we will randomize:
Participants will be randomly assigned to each treatment condition using block randomization. That is, we will achieve balanced groups by creating a list containing equal numbers of acetaminophen and placebo assignments (130 each). We will randomize the list, treat the first element of the list as the assignment for the first participant, then assign participants as they arrive while moving down the list.
registration_responses.q17.question:
Measured Variables 

DVs -----
Moral Transgression DVs:

Judgment of moral condemnation: “How morally wrong do you think this action is? 
from 1 to 7; (Not at all wrong to Extremely wrong)

Judgment of emotion: “How negative does this action make you feel?
from 1 to 7; (Not at all negative to Extremely negative)

Preference for Utilitarianism/Deontology:
We will create U (preference for utilitarianism) and D (preference for deontology) parameters using the method outlined in Conway and Gawronski (2013)*. See Indices section for more information.

IVs:

Individual Differences:
Three Domain Disgust Scale (TDDS)
Baer Five Facets of Mindfulness Scale 
Toronto Empathy Questionnaire
Big Five Aspects Scale (N)
Moral Foundation Questionnaire (MFQ)
Condition Guess
Recent food intake

Moral Transgression Type:
- 10 Purity Domain Transgressions from Clifford et al., 2015
- 10 Harm Domain Transgressions from Clifford et al., 2015
- 10 Social Norm Violations from Clifford et al., 2015
- Presentation of Transgression Type: random sampling without replacement.
- Note: Harm and Purity transgressions are matched on arousal and wrongness (Arousal: Mharm=4.3, Mpurity =4.2; Wrongness: Mharm=3.8, Mpurity =3.6; t’s less than 1.63, p’s greater than.12)

Moral Dilemmas:
We will use the congruent and incongruent moral dilemmas developed by Conway and Gawronski (2013)*. Because of time constraints,  we chose the six shortest dilemmas, each of which contains a congruent and incongruent version. Dilemmas will be presented in random order without repetition (random sample without replacement). The dilemmas are listed in the attachment below. 

*Conway, P. & Gawronski, B. (2013). Deontological and utilitarian inclinations in moral decision making: a process dissociation approach. Journal of personality and social psychology, 104(2), 216. Chicago
registration_responses.q18.question:
All individual difference scales:
We will score scales according to the instructions provided by the original authors. For scales for which no instructions have been published, we take the arithmetic mean. To assess scale reliability, we will report Cronbach’s alphas and flag any alphas less than 0.6 as a limitation of measurement.
D and U Indices:
Each dilemma ends by asking if it is appropriate to do the action described at the end of the dilemma (Yes or No). The U and D indices thus represent conditional probabilities, which will be derived from participants' choices of Yes vs No to the appropriateness questions at the end of each dilemma. 
To calculate the D and U indices for each participant using the process dissociation approach described in Conway and Gawronski (2013), we will use the following formulas: 
Preference for Utilitarianism: U =􏰁 p(􏰋unacceptable 􏰈| congruent) -􏰌 p(􏰋unacceptable | incongruent􏰌)
Preference for Deontology: D =􏰁 p(􏰋unacceptable 􏰈| incongruent) / (1 - U)
For more information, see pages 219 - 220 of the attached article.

data.value: It's complicated. We have already collected some data but explain in Question 8 why readers may consider this a valid pre-registration nevertheless.

name.value: Investigating linguistic distancing in psychotherapy: Dissertation Study 3

other.value: As noted above, primary analyses will be conducted on the internalizing symptoms measure (which is the sum of the depression and anxiety symptoms measures). However, we will report statistics for analyses conducted on depression and anxiety symptoms separately in the discussion, for completeness).

sample.value: The current preregistered analyses will be conducted on the “validation” holdout dataset from 2,500 Talkspace users who meet inclusion criteria for the study (i.e., 18 years or older, at least 6-weeks of therapy, and at least 3 symptom measures completed). No analyses have been performed on this holdout dataset yet, and all replication analyses will be conducted as outlined in this preregistration.

analyses.value:
General modeling notes. For many analyses, mixed-effects models will be used. Mixed-effects models allow for repeated measurements to be nested within participants by adding a random effect of participant. Model-building analyses in the exploratory dataset also revealed that adding a random slope of time in therapy greatly improved model fit for models in which time in therapy is a predictor. As such, we again plan to test whether adding a random slope for time in therapy improves model fit in the validation dataset, and if so, we will include it in mixed-effect models. Additionally, we plan to conduct primary analyses on internalizing symptoms. However, we also plan to report statistics for analyses of depression and anxiety separately in the supplement, for thoroughness. 

1) Do clients’ symptoms decrease over the course of therapy? We will use a mixed-effects model to test for a linear relationship between days in treatment and internalizing symptoms. 

2) Does client linguistic distance increase over the course of therapy? We will first conduct a series of mixed-effects models to explore whether the traditional measure of linguistic distance increases over therapy and if this reflects a general issue in which present-tense verbs, past-tense verbs, future-tense verbs, first-person singular pronouns, and pronouns that are not first-person singular all increase over time in therapy. If all of these word types increase over therapy, we will have justification to use the newer measures of temporal and social distance in our analyses. We will use two mixed-effects models to test whether temporal distance (i.e., the proportion of verbs that were not in the present tense) and social distance (i.e., the proportion of pronouns that were not first-person singular) were significantly related to time in therapy. 

3) Does client linguistic distance track client symptoms? Two mixed-effects models will test whether clients’ temporal and social distance are significantly related to internalizing symptoms. Prior research has shown that in longitudinal designs, it is important to decompose predictors into their within-person and between-person sources of variance (Bolger & Laurenceau, 2013; Enders & Tofighi, 2007). As such, we will follow prior work in decomposing the measures of temporal and social distance into within-person and between-person components. In essence, a variable representing the within-person fluctuation in temporal distance will be created by subtracting each individual’s mean temporal distance score from the score of each of their observations (i.e., producing a variable representing within-person deviations, centered around individuals’ means). This will be repeated for social distance. Then, a variable representing between-person variance in temporal distance will be constructed by subtracting the overall group mean of temporal distance from that participant’s average temporal distance (i.e., a variable that is constant within each participant and represent how their mean level deviates from the group’s mean). The same will be repeated for social distance. These within-person and between-person variables will then be entered simultaneously in mixed-effects models to test how internalizing symptoms relate to both within- and between-person variance in linguistic distance. 

4) Do within-person shifts in linguistic distance mediate changes in internalizing symptoms over the course of treatment? If the analyses above provide support for each leg of the mediation model described above, we will then conduct mediation analyses to formally test whether within-person increases in temporal or social distance over the course of treatment mediate symptom changes. As described above, we will use measures of temporal and social distance that are decomposed into their within-person and between-person components in these models. Typically, mediation analyses utilize bootstrapping methods (i.e., randomly sampling from the original dataset with preplacement thousands of times) to generate many samples from which a confidence window can be constructed to test the significance of mediation model (Davison & Hinkley, 1997). However, the appropriate method for bootstrapping multilevel data is not clear, as random samples can drawn at the participant level, at the observation level, or at both participant and observation levels. We thus used Bayesian analytic procedures, which do not involve bootstrapping methods, for our mediation analyses to sidestep this issue (for a similar approach, see Rodman et al., under review). Consequently, we will conduct Bayesian mediation analyses testing whether temporal and/or social distance mediate the relationship between time in therapy and internalizing symptoms. Like the mixed-effects models described above, the Bayesian regression models will include a random effect of participant to account for the multi-level nature of the dataset. To provide relatively unbiased starting points for Bayesian analyses, we will supply weakly informative priors (gaussian distribution of M = 0, SD = 10) for all regressors in the models. Bayesian analyses will be implemented using the Stan language in R (Stan Development Team, 2017). Two Markov chains using the Monte Carlo No U-Turn Sampler (Hoffman & Gelman, 2014) will approximate the posterior distribution of each regressor across 12,500 iterations, with the first 2,500 iterations discarded as burn-in. The indirect effect (i.e., the a × b pathway for the within-person parameter) and proportion mediated [i.e., indirect effect / (indirect effect + direct effect) × 100] will be computed for each mediation model. A significant mediation will be said to occur when the 95% credible range (CR) of posterior density for the indirect effect does not include 0. 

5) Does therapist linguistic distance relate to treatment outcomes? As a simple preliminary analysis of this question, we will first test for a simple correlation between a client’s overall symptom reduction (i.e., final internalizing symptom score – initial internalizing symptom score) and their therapist’s overall level of linguistic distance. We will also test whether this relationship holds after controlling for clients’ baseline internalizing symptom scores. We will then test whether therapist linguistic distance indeed moderates the mediation model proposed above. This involves adding therapist linguistic distance as an interaction term to mixed-effects regressions for each of the legs of the mediation model. [i.e., does therapist linguistic distance interact with time in therapy in predicting client symptoms (c path moderation)? Does therapist linguistic distance interact with time in therapy in predicting client linguistic distance (a path moderation)? Does therapist linguistic distance interact with client linguistic distance in predicting client outcomes (b path moderation)?] We will use client temporal and social distance variables for these analyses (as described above), but we will use the traditional measure of linguistic distance for the therapist’s language (as in Nook et al., 2017, 2019). This will be done because the use of a single measure of average therapist linguistic distance across the entire study precludes the need to standardize or adjust for changes in verb or pronoun use across time. When significant interactions emerge in regressions, we will use simple slopes analyses to unpack the direction of the effect. If we observe interactions in the c path as well as either the a or b paths, we will conduct a full moderated mediation analysis within a Bayesian framework, as described above.

6) Can treatment progress be inferred from text data alone? We will utilize finite mixture modeling techniques (Leisch, 2004) to cluster participants based on their linguistic distance at the text level. In essence, mixture regressions identify clusters of individuals depending on similarities of joint distributions among variables. In other words, participants who tend to have the same relationship between two variables are grouped together into a cluster. In this case, we will use mixture regressions to cluster individuals based on how their social and temporal distance in individual text messages varied across time (e.g., grouping clients whose temporal distance increased over time into one cluster and grouping clients whose temporal distance decreased over time into a different cluster). Mixture regression models will be conducted on a dataset that includes the temporal and social distance score for every text sent by clients to their primary therapist over the course of therapy. In this dataset, time in therapy will be quantified as a decimal value that includes the proportion of a day that has passed since the first text sent between the patient. One set of mixture regressions will be used to group participants into clusters based on their trajectory of temporal distance across time, and a second set of mixture regressions will group participants based on social distance across time. We will conduct mixture regression models that group participants into one, two, three, and four clusters, and then select the number of clusters that provide the best fit, as determined by AIC. For additional stability and model fit, mixture regressions for each cluster size will be implemented 10 times to account for subtle differences that can emerge depending on random starting points of the clustering algorithm, and the best fitting model for each number of clusters will be selected. Mixture regressions sill include a random effect of subject to account for nesting of text messages within subjects.

dependent.value:
Dependent variables for all analyses include:

Time in therapy. Time in therapy will be defined as the number of days that have passed since the start of therapy (defined as the date of the first text message between the client and their primary therapist).

Depression symptoms. Depression symptoms are measured via the Personal Health Questionnaire-8 (PHQ-8; Kroenke et al., 2009) questionnaire, which is administered to clients approximately every three weeks. Responses on the PHQ-8 are summed to produce a measure of depression symptoms.

Anxiety symptoms. Anxiety symptoms are measured via the Generalized Anxiety Disorder-7 (GAD-7; Spitzer, Kroenke, Williams, & Löwe, 2006) questionnaire, which is also administered approximately every three weeks. Responses on the GAD-7 are summed to produce a measure of anxiety symptoms.

Internalizing symptoms. Analyses in the exploratory dataset revealed that depression and anxiety scores were strongly correlated and that results were highly consistent across the two measures. As such, primary analyses will be conducted on the sum of these two measures (similar to Kroenke et al., 2016), which we call a measure of internalizing symptoms.

Linguistic distance. The linguistic distance for each text will be computed following prior work (see Mehl et al., 2012; Nook et al., 2017, 2019).  Linguistic Inquiry and Word Count (LIWC; Pennebaker, Booth, & Francis, 2007) software will be used to compute the percentage of words that fall into each component of the linguistic distance composite measure (i.e., first-person singular pronouns, present-tense verbs, discrepancy words, articles, and words longer than 6 letters). These percentages will be z-scored across messages. Use of first-person singular pronouns, present-tense verbs, and discrepancy words will be reverse-scored (by multiplying their z-scores by -1), and then these resulting scores will be averaged to produce linguistic distance scores for each text message. 

Subcomponents of linguistic distance. Analyses will also examine how subcomponents of linguistic distance (e.g., the proportion of words in a text that are present-tense verbs or first-person singular pronouns) vary across time in therapy. These variables will be the raw outputs from the LIWC software, which extracts the proportion of words in each text that fall into relevant linguistic categories.

Temporal distance. Analyses in the exploratory dataset revealed that present-tense, past-tense, and future-tense verbs all increased over time in therapy. Thus, to get an accurate measure of linguistic distance it is important to account for these time-related shifts in overall verb use, rather than using the traditional measure of linguistic distance for client texts. As such, we will create a measure of temporal distance by computing the proportion of verbs in text messages that are not present-tense verbs for each of the client’s text messages [i.e., (past + future) / (past + future + present)].

Social distance. Similarly, the proportion of both first-person singular pronouns and all other pronouns increased across treatment. As such, we will create a measure of social distance by computing the proportion of pronouns that are not first-person singular for each of the client’s text messages [i.e., (second-person + first-person plural + third-person singular + third-person plural) / (second-person + first-person plural + third-person singular + third-person plural + first-person singular)].

conditions.value: Not applicable. The study design does not include assignment to conditions. The study involves analyses of existing data in which clients received therapy from therapists on the Talkspace platform.

hypothesis.value:
Internalizing forms of psychopathology like anxiety and depression have been associated with both insufficient use of adaptive emotion regulation strategies (e.g., cognitive reappraisal) and excessive use of maladaptive emotion regulation strategies (e.g., rumination; Aldao, Nolen-Hoeksema, & Schweizer, 2010; Gross & Jazaieri, 2014; Sheppes et al., 2015). Hence, shifting emotion regulation from maladaptive to adaptive strategies is an important target of clinical interventions (Berking, Ebert, Cuijpers, & Hofmann, 2013; Mennin, Fresco, Ritter, & Heimberg, 2015). Prior work taking a psycholinguistic approach to emotion regulation has shown that “linguistic distancing” (i.e., using language that increases psychological distance between oneself and the topic of discussion), for example by reducing use of present-tense verbs and first-person singular pronouns, is associated with effective use of adaptive emotion regulation strategies (Kross et al., 2014; Nook, Schleider, & Somerville, 2017; Nook, Vidal Bustamante, Cho, & Somerville, 2019; Orvell, Kross, & Gelman, 2017; Shahane & Denny, 2019). Consistent with the idea that low linguistic distance is associated with both poor emotion regulation and internalizing symptoms, prior work shows that people suffering from more severe depression and anxiety symptoms tend to use more first-person singular pronouns (i.e., they speak with less linguistic distance; Brockmeyer et al., 2015; Edwards & Holtzman, 2017). Taken together, these results suggest that linguistic distance might be a marker (or even a mechanism) of treatment response in psychotherapy. However, little research has examined linguistic distance in the context of therapy. 

As such, the current study seeks to address six key research questions concerning the roles of both client and therapist linguistic distance in psychotherapy. We test these research questions by making use of data from Talkspace, a platform for asynchronous messaging-based therapy. Both text messages (which comprise therapeutic exchanges between thereapists and clients) and self-report symptom measures from a total of 6,229 participants will be analyzed for this study. These participants were randomly divided into exploratory (N = 3,729) and validation (N = 2,500) datasets. At present, the analyses described below have been implemented in the exploratory dataset only. No analyses have been conducted on the validation subsample (i.e., the validation subsample is a true holdout dataset). As such, the current preregistration serves to preregister the analyses we plan to conduct in the validation dataset with the aim of replicating key results found in the exploratory dataset. Below we outline the overall hypothesized model, research questions, and relevant analyses.

Overall hypothesized model. Based on the literature described above, this study’s research questions are organized around an overall moderated mediation model in which increased linguistic distance mediates the relationship between time in therapy and reduced internalizing symptoms. We propose that (i) clients’ internalizing symptoms will decrease over therapy, (ii) linguistic distance will increase over the course of therapy (potentially reflecting improved emotion regulation ability), and (iii) linguistic distance will be inversely correlated with internalizing symptoms. Together, we hypothesize that these relationships will fit into a mediation model in which increased linguistic distance mediate reduced symptoms over time in therapy. However, we also hypothesize that a therapist’s linguistic distance will moderate this mediation. In particular, we hypothesize that therapists who speak with higher linguistic distance will have patients who more strongly reduce their symptoms. We posit that this moderation will arise because therapists who use more distanced language will in turn induce larger increases in their client’s linguistic distance over the course of therapy (i.e., therapist linguistic distance will moderate the a path of the mediation model). As such, we hypothesize that therapist linguistic distance will amplify the linguistic distance mediation model described above. The research questions below chart each component of this model.

1) Do clients’ symptoms of depression and anxiety decrease over the course of therapy? We will first test whether a client’s internalizing symptoms decrease over time in therapy (i.e., the c path of the mediation model). We hypothesize a significant negative relationship between time in therapy and internalizing symptoms.

2) Does client linguistic distance increase over the course of therapy? We will then test whether a client’s linguistic distance increases over time in treatment (i.e., the a path of the mediation model). We hypothesize that linguistic distance will be positively related to time in therapy. 

3) Does client linguistic distance track client internalizing symptoms? We will then test whether a client’s linguistic distance is related to the severity of their internalizing symptoms (i.e., the b path in the mediation model). We hypothesize that symptoms will be negatively related to linguistic distance. 

4) Do within-person shifts in linguistic distance mediate changes in symptoms over the course of treatment? After testing each leg of the mediation model described above, we will then conduct a mediation analysis to formally test whether increasing linguistic distance over the course of treatment mediates symptom changes over time. We hypothesize that increases in linguistic distance mediate decreased symptoms across therapy.

5) Does therapist linguistic distance relate to treatment outcomes? Turning to therapist language, our next research question investigates whether therapists who use more distant language will be more successful in reducing their clients’ symptoms. We hypothesize that clients will experience greater reductions in symptoms if their therapists speak with higher linguistic distance. Additionally, we hypothesize that this overall relationship between therapist language and client symptoms fit within a moderated mediation model, in which higher therapist linguistic distance will strengthen the mediation pathway described above. Specifically, we hypothesize that therapist linguistic distance will moderate how strongly a client’s linguistic distance increases over time in therapy (i.e., the a path of the mediation model).

6) Can treatment progress be inferred from text data alone? As a supplemental/alternative approach to the regression analyses described above, we sought to test whether clients could be grouped into clusters based on their linguistic data alone and whether these clusters would differ in their symptom levels and treatment outcomes. We hypothesized that clients could indeed be clustered according to their trajectories of linguistic distance over time in therapy and that these clusters would differ in their initial symptom levels, final symptom levels, and change in symptom levels across therapy.

registration_responses.data: It's complicated. We have already collected some data but explain in Question 8 why readers may consider this a valid pre-registration nevertheless.
registration_responses.name: Investigating linguistic distancing in psychotherapy: Dissertation Study 3
registration_responses.other: As noted above, primary analyses will be conducted on the internalizing symptoms measure (which is the sum of the depression and anxiety symptoms measures). However, we will report statistics for analyses conducted on depression and anxiety symptoms separately in the discussion, for completeness).
registration_responses.sample: The current preregistered analyses will be conducted on the “validation” holdout dataset from 2,500 Talkspace users who meet inclusion criteria for the study (i.e., 18 years or older, at least 6-weeks of therapy, and at least 3 symptom measures completed). No analyses have been performed on this holdout dataset yet, and all replication analyses will be conducted as outlined in this preregistration.
registration_responses.analyses:
General modeling notes. For many analyses, mixed-effects models will be used. Mixed-effects models allow for repeated measurements to be nested within participants by adding a random effect of participant. Model-building analyses in the exploratory dataset also revealed that adding a random slope of time in therapy greatly improved model fit for models in which time in therapy is a predictor. As such, we again plan to test whether adding a random slope for time in therapy improves model fit in the validation dataset, and if so, we will include it in mixed-effect models. Additionally, we plan to conduct primary analyses on internalizing symptoms. However, we also plan to report statistics for analyses of depression and anxiety separately in the supplement, for thoroughness. 

1) Do clients’ symptoms decrease over the course of therapy? We will use a mixed-effects model to test for a linear relationship between days in treatment and internalizing symptoms. 

2) Does client linguistic distance increase over the course of therapy? We will first conduct a series of mixed-effects models to explore whether the traditional measure of linguistic distance increases over therapy and if this reflects a general issue in which present-tense verbs, past-tense verbs, future-tense verbs, first-person singular pronouns, and pronouns that are not first-person singular all increase over time in therapy. If all of these word types increase over therapy, we will have justification to use the newer measures of temporal and social distance in our analyses. We will use two mixed-effects models to test whether temporal distance (i.e., the proportion of verbs that were not in the present tense) and social distance (i.e., the proportion of pronouns that were not first-person singular) were significantly related to time in therapy. 

3) Does client linguistic distance track client symptoms? Two mixed-effects models will test whether clients’ temporal and social distance are significantly related to internalizing symptoms. Prior research has shown that in longitudinal designs, it is important to decompose predictors into their within-person and between-person sources of variance (Bolger & Laurenceau, 2013; Enders & Tofighi, 2007). As such, we will follow prior work in decomposing the measures of temporal and social distance into within-person and between-person components. In essence, a variable representing the within-person fluctuation in temporal distance will be created by subtracting each individual’s mean temporal distance score from the score of each of their observations (i.e., producing a variable representing within-person deviations, centered around individuals’ means). This will be repeated for social distance. Then, a variable representing between-person variance in temporal distance will be constructed by subtracting the overall group mean of temporal distance from that participant’s average temporal distance (i.e., a variable that is constant within each participant and represent how their mean level deviates from the group’s mean). The same will be repeated for social distance. These within-person and between-person variables will then be entered simultaneously in mixed-effects models to test how internalizing symptoms relate to both within- and between-person variance in linguistic distance. 

4) Do within-person shifts in linguistic distance mediate changes in internalizing symptoms over the course of treatment? If the analyses above provide support for each leg of the mediation model described above, we will then conduct mediation analyses to formally test whether within-person increases in temporal or social distance over the course of treatment mediate symptom changes. As described above, we will use measures of temporal and social distance that are decomposed into their within-person and between-person components in these models. Typically, mediation analyses utilize bootstrapping methods (i.e., randomly sampling from the original dataset with preplacement thousands of times) to generate many samples from which a confidence window can be constructed to test the significance of mediation model (Davison & Hinkley, 1997). However, the appropriate method for bootstrapping multilevel data is not clear, as random samples can drawn at the participant level, at the observation level, or at both participant and observation levels. We thus used Bayesian analytic procedures, which do not involve bootstrapping methods, for our mediation analyses to sidestep this issue (for a similar approach, see Rodman et al., under review). Consequently, we will conduct Bayesian mediation analyses testing whether temporal and/or social distance mediate the relationship between time in therapy and internalizing symptoms. Like the mixed-effects models described above, the Bayesian regression models will include a random effect of participant to account for the multi-level nature of the dataset. To provide relatively unbiased starting points for Bayesian analyses, we will supply weakly informative priors (gaussian distribution of M = 0, SD = 10) for all regressors in the models. Bayesian analyses will be implemented using the Stan language in R (Stan Development Team, 2017). Two Markov chains using the Monte Carlo No U-Turn Sampler (Hoffman & Gelman, 2014) will approximate the posterior distribution of each regressor across 12,500 iterations, with the first 2,500 iterations discarded as burn-in. The indirect effect (i.e., the a × b pathway for the within-person parameter) and proportion mediated [i.e., indirect effect / (indirect effect + direct effect) × 100] will be computed for each mediation model. A significant mediation will be said to occur when the 95% credible range (CR) of posterior density for the indirect effect does not include 0. 

5) Does therapist linguistic distance relate to treatment outcomes? As a simple preliminary analysis of this question, we will first test for a simple correlation between a client’s overall symptom reduction (i.e., final internalizing symptom score – initial internalizing symptom score) and their therapist’s overall level of linguistic distance. This involves adding therapist linguistic distance as an interaction term to mixed-effects regressions for each of the legs of the mediation model. [i.e., does therapist linguistic distance interact with time in therapy in predicting client symptoms (c path moderation)? Does therapist linguistic distance interact with time in therapy in predicting client linguistic distance (a path moderation)? Does therapist linguistic distance interact with client linguistic distance in predicting client outcomes (b path moderation)?] We will use client temporal and social distance variables for these analyses (as described above), but we will use the traditional measure of linguistic distance for the therapist’s language (as in Nook et al., 2017, 2019). 6) Can treatment progress be inferred from text data alone? We will utilize finite mixture modeling techniques (Leisch, 2004) to cluster participants based on their linguistic distance at the text level. In essence, mixture regressions identify clusters of individuals depending on similarities of joint distributions among variables. In other words, participants who tend to have the same relationship between two variables are grouped together into a cluster. In this case, we will use mixture regressions to cluster individuals based on how their social and temporal distance in individual text messages varied across time (e.g., grouping clients whose temporal distance increased over time into one cluster and grouping clients whose temporal distance decreased over time into a different cluster). attributes.title: The impact of formal explanations on kindhood and essentialism

q1.value: The impact of formal explanations on kindhood and essentialism (no pictures)

q3.value: Tweak of earlier project (https://osf.io/gb7fm), without pictures to reduce possible interference with the essentialism measure from the particular picture stimuli, and with proper names to maintain referential clarity.

question.value: Participants in the formal explanation condition will read formal explanations of the form "[Proper name].... because she/he is a Zarpie." Participants in the generics condition will read generic statements of the form "Zarpies....". Participants in the specific control condition will read specific variations of the generic statements of the form "This Zarpie, named [proper name],....".

We will use 3 measures of kindhood (inherent similarity, heterogeneous [reverse-coded], inductive potential) and 4 measures of essentialism (internal cause, constructed category [reverse-coded], constructed boundaries [reverse-coded], immutability) borrowed directly from Noyes & Keil, 2019, study 1.
Each measure is a 6-point Likert scale that will be coded 0-1 (or 1-0 for reverse-coded measures) in evenly spaced intervals, and will be averaged into an overall measure of kindhood or essentialism.
Linear mixed effects model with condition (formal explanation, specific), measure (kind, essence), and their interaction, with participant as a random intercept.
