q3.value:
The UK is unique in having allowed under 18s to legally engage in a number of gambling or “gambling-like” activities for a number of years. For example, national lottery products can be purchased from the age of 16, and some low-stakes slot machines (“Category D fruit machines”) can be legally played at any age.

This is a retrospective study correlating recollected usage of these legal youth gambling products with current gambling problems and gambling harms in a group of UK adult gamblers. This study is relevant to the current landscape, where a number of gambling-like opportunities have recently become accessible to under 18s (e.g., “loot boxes” in video games), but not enough time has yet passed to see how these new products might contribute to later life gambling problems and harm.

The survey will not investigate illegal youth gambling, as from a regulatory standpoint this is more of a secondary enforcement issue.

q4.value:
We predict there will be positive correlations between recollected usage of legal youth gambling and
adult problem gambling severity, as measured by the problem gambling severity index
 
An alpha level of .01 will be used, adjusting the conventional .05 level for the fact that five main comparisons are being made.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
This is a correlational survey. One element is the measurement of adult gambling problems, via the Problem Gambling Severity Index. The main novel aspect is the recollected legal usage of four gambling products which are available to under 18s:
 
National lottery tickets -- a standard international lottery, legal to use from the age of 16
National lottery scratchcards -- standard instant scratchards, legal to use from the age of 16
Category D fruit machines -- electronic gambling machines with a maximum bet of 10p and a maximum payout of £5. Legal to use from any age.
Coin push machines -- arcade machines where coins of value up to 10p are wagered in the hope of winning more coins. Legal to use from any age.
Crane grab machines -- arcade machines costing up to £1 to play, where the aim is to successfully grab a prize worth up to £50. Legal to use from any age.
 
These gambling products vary by the age they can be used from and also the extent to which they resemble conventional gambling products. Each of these products will come with a short block of descriptive text and a picture, so that each question will be clear to participants. Descriptive text will be uploaded to the study page’s OSF link.
 
The survey also contains a demographics block.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
We aim to collect 1,000 current UK nationals who are adult gamblers. Participants will be collected via Prolific Academic, and Prolific’s pre-screeners used to ensure they satisfy the inclusion criteria. We will exclude any participant who tries to complete the survey twice. They will be paid at least £.50 for taking part, which should equate to more than £6/hour pro-rata. The study should be available on Prolific for no longer than a week.
 
Participants will additionally be pre-screened to be aged 40 or younger. This is because one of the gambling products, national lottery scratchcards, was only introduced in 1995. We want to ensure that all participants had an opportunity to legally use these products while being aged under 18. By removing participants aged over 40 we also reduce the extent to which memory biases might affect the results.

The main novel measured variable is recollected legal usage of that legal youth gambling product, measured on a 5-point Likert scale:
 
“How often do you recall using Category D fruit machines while being under the age of 18?
Never
Rarely
Occasionally
Frequently
Very frequently”
 
Each of these questions will also contain descriptive text explaining what that gambling product is.
 
We decided to use frequency rather than expenditure, since expenditure may vary due to staking limits varying between the products, and the products potentially being appealing to people at different age ranges.
 
We will also collect the Problem Gambling Severity Index.

The goal of the analysis is to determine whether increased levels of engagement with legal youth gambling products is associated with adult gambling problems. This will be done for each of the five youth gambling products separately.
 
The dependent variable for each product is the Problem Gambling Severity Index (PGSI). PGSI is very likely to be positively skewed. Thus, we will run a test for skewness. Using Bulmer’s (1979) classic skewness descriptives, we will declare PGSI to be positively skewed if the relevant skewness statistic is > 1. If PGSI is positively skewed, we will use a log (+1) transformed version of the variable. If PGSI is not skewed, we will use raw scores. Using a log-transformed version of skewed dependent variables, particularly the PGSI, is relatively common in gambling and related literature (e.g., Browne et al., 2019).
 
The independent variables (frequency of engagement in each form) are coded as 0 = ‘never’, 1 = ‘rarely’, 2 = ‘occasionally’, 3 = ‘frequently’, 4 = ‘very frequently’. The response option of ‘never’ is qualitatively different to the other response options. Therefore, we will split the research question for each gambling product into two orthogonal (independent) aspects:
 
Is any level of engagement with a youth gambling product versus having never used that product associated with adult PGSI scores?
For gamblers who have used a given gambling product, are increased levels of recollected usage associated with adult PGSI scores?
 
A significance level of .01 will be used, since we are introducing a Bonferroni correction for the fact that five products are being tested. A further Bonferroni correction is not introduced for splitting the overall research question into aspects 1) and 2), as these are individual sub-components of the overall research question. Either the “never vs any frequency” or “frequency” components of the independent variables being statistically significant will support the hypothesis.
 
At this stage we as yet do not know how many participants will endorse having engaged in each of the five types of legal youth gambling. It is possible that almost all, or almost none, of participants will report engaging in a specific form. If a given gambling product was used by nearly everyone in the sample, then we will be unable to detect reliable estimates for aspect 1) above. If a given gambling product was used by almost nobody in the sample, then we will be unable to detect reliable estimates for both 1) and 2) above.
 
Therefore, we will not run analysis 1) for a given gambling product is used by .95 or more of the sample. We will not run either analysis 1) or 2) if a given gambling product is used by less than .05 of the sample.
 
The analysis will be performed via generalized linear models programmed in R. Part 2) will be analyzed by treating different levels of youth gambling engagement as an interval scale.
 
Note that the ‘never vs any frequency’ variable will be coded 1 = ‘no’ and 0 = ‘yes’, so a negative coefficient will indicate an association between that form and PGSI. This is because the frequency variable will be coded as 0 (never) to 4 (very frequently), and the coefficient for this variable will indicate the association between frequency and PGSI for those who score 0 on the never vs any frequency variable (i.e., those who DO engage in the form). For frequency, a positive coefficient predicting PGSI will support the hypothesis.
 
Additional analyses are not related to the determination of whether the main experimental hypothesis is supported or not, but will be considered as exploratory research to present a wider picture for the overall paper. These analyses include adding age to each model as a covariate, and an interaction between age and engagement in forms that are found to have a statistically significant relationship with adult PGSI. Other collected demographic information of gender, education, and occupation will be reported only in the Participants section of the paper, and not included in the statistical analysis.
 
References
 
Browne, M., Hing, N., Rockloff, M., Russell, A. M., Greer, N., Nicoll, F., & Smith, G. (2019). A multivariate evaluation of 25 proximal and distal risk-factors for gambling-related harm. Journal of Clinical Medicine, 8(4), 509.
Bulmer, M. G. (1979). Principles of statistics. Courier Corporation.

q3.value: This is study 2 in this project, following up on the initial study investigating a task that is more sensitive to cognitive control mechanisms, particularly in terms of the dual mechanisms of control framework. The first study showed evidence for the titration hypothesis versus a model representing a more dichotomous view of proactive and reactive control. This second study adds working memory capacity, which has been shown previously to be strongly related to cognitive control use.

q4.value: Higher working memory is often found to be related to more proactive control use and low working memory is associated with less consistent proactive control use and more reactive control use. So, I predict a similar pattern here. Higher working memory will lead to faster and more accurate responding on the trials where proactive control is the optimal strategy, and relatively lower accuracy on trials where reactive control is the optimal strategy. In terms of modeling the data, higher working memory individuals should be more sensitive to the task demands leading to cleaner titration patterns and larger proactive control index scores. Low working memory should be associated with overall slower RTs and lower accuracy, except on trials where reactive control is the optimal strategy where they will have relatively fewer errors. I also anticipate lower proactive index scores and less sensitivity to task demands resulting in less clean titration patterns or possible no evidence of titration pattern.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: This is a mixed design with working memory as a between-subjects factor and trial types as within-subject factors. No counterbalancing is required for this study.

q9.value: The trials are randomized by the task, so each subject will see stimuli in a different order. There is no additional randomization.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Subjects are to be between the ages of 18 and 30, fluent in English, and have normal or corrected-to-normal vision. Subjects will mostly be from the Intro Psych subject pool, receiving partial course credit for participation, but some may be paid at a rate of $5/30mins. Data will be excluded additionally if mean accuracy is below chance on 3 or more of the 10 blocks of trials because correct response times are going to be evaluated and that would be too few trials for meaningful analysis.

q13.value: The target is 150 subjects completing 800 trials each.

q14.value: Time is one major consideration. Additionally, 95 was the final sample in study 1 and was sufficient to model the data. However, the addition of working memory adds a layer of complexity that requires the addition of more subjects.

q15.value: Stopping may occur if at least 100 are collected but the semester (time constraint) concludes. Fewer than 100 would not be analyzed, data collection would then resume at a later time.

question.value: The predictability of the subsequent response on trial n+1 is manipulated within-subjects.

We are measuring the accuracy and response times for each trial. They will be organized by current and previous trial stimulus to view any differences that occur in what should be proactive-beneficial trials and reactive-beneficial trials. Additionally, working memory will be measured via operation and symmetry complex span tasks, with the composite score then used in analyses.

The proactive control index is the following calculation (mean of "5-N" trial correct RTs) - (("1-N" correct RT mean + "9-N" correct RT mean) / 2).

Working memory again is using a composite score, that is  (Zscore from Ospan + Zscore from Sspan)/2

Models will be bayesian ANOVA models with current stimulus, previous stimulus as factors and subject as random intercept, as in study 1 in an effort to replicate. Working memory will then be added to these models to evaluate the effect of working memory. Separate models will evaluate mean RT, RT ISD, and Error rate. Working memory will also be correlated with proactive index. Further, models with different previous-stimulus groupings will be compared to evaluate the competing titration and dichotomous hypotheses.

q20.value: Data will be recoded in that the previous trial type is mirrored about 5, so 1 and 9 are grouped, 2 and 8, etc. Further, the current stimulus is recoded as the numerical distance from the previous stimulus. This is done with simple formulas in excel before data analysis. The grouping variable is also a recoded form of the previous-stimulus variable, artificially grouping the trial types according the the different theories.

q22.value: Subjects with lower than 50% accuracy on three or more blocks will be excluded. Incorrect trials are excluded from RT analyses.

attributes.title: Monitoring and Managing Forest Resources in Liberia

q1.value: Monitoring and Managing Forest Resources in Liberia

q2.value: Darin Christensen | Alexandra C. Hartman | Cyrus Samii

q8.value: Registration prior to realization of outcomes

q15.value: This experiment is part of the EGAP metaketa on natural resource governance, examining the effects of community monitoring as a tool to promote efficient and sustainable natural resource use. In our case, we examine the effects of monitoring on the use of community forests in rural Liberia.

q16.value: As noted in the pre-analysis plan, our hypotheses concern the effects of community monitoring (CM) and are as follows: (H1) CM reduces logging by families within the communities (see the pre-analysis plan for more on "families" in this context). (H2) CM reduces monitoring costs. (H3) CM increases citizens’ expected value from outside deals and revenue sharing. We can also use the model to determine how these changes affect welfare: (H4) CM increases families welfare. (H5) CM increases the chief’s welfare. (H6) The negative effect of CM on logging by families is amplified by factors that increase the expected value from outside deals. Note as well that the results of this study will be used to test hypotheses posed in the metaketa meta-pre-analysis plan, which is being filed separately.

q17.value: We will test these hypotheses with two-sided significance tests on treatment effect estimates from regressions that adjust for randomization stratum (in our case district) fixed effects, and that weight by the inverse of treatment assignment. The weighting accounts for the fact that we use a restricted randomization that imposes a covariate balance constraint on the treatment assignment. The covariates that we balanced in this restricted randomization include population density, nightlight emissions, elevation, average annual precipitation, average temperature, previous forest loss, distance from Monrovia, and distance from a primary road.

registration_responses.q1: Monitoring and Managing Forest Resources in Liberia
registration_responses.q2: Darin Christensen | Alexandra C. Hartman | Cyrus Samii
registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to realization of outcomes
registration_responses.q15: This experiment is part of the EGAP metaketa on natural resource governance, examining the effects of community monitoring as a tool to promote efficient and sustainable natural resource use. In our case, we examine the effects of monitoring on the use of community forests in rural Liberia.
registration_responses.q16: As noted in the pre-analysis plan, our hypotheses concern the effects of community monitoring (CM) and are as follows: (H1) CM reduces logging by families within the communities (see the pre-analysis plan for more on "families" in this context). (H2) CM reduces monitoring costs. (H3) CM increases citizens’ expected value from outside deals and revenue sharing. We can also use the model to determine how these changes affect welfare: (H4) CM increases families welfare. (H5) CM increases the chief’s welfare. (H6) The negative effect of CM on logging by families is amplified by factors that increase the expected value from outside deals. Note as well that the results of this study will be used to test hypotheses posed in the metaketa meta-pre-analysis plan, which is being filed separately.
registration_responses.q17: We will test these hypotheses with two-sided significance tests on treatment effect estimates from regressions that adjust for randomization stratum (in our case district) fixed effects, and that weight by the inverse of treatment assignment. The weighting accounts for the fact that we use a restricted randomization that imposes a covariate balance constraint on the treatment assignment. The covariates that we balanced in this restricted randomization include population density, nightlight emissions, elevation, average annual precipitation, average temperature, previous forest loss, distance from Monrovia, and distance from a primary road.

attributes.title: Gender, Meat Consumption, and Openness to Going Vegetarian

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: Gender, Meat Consumption, and Openness to Going Vegetarian

analyses.value:
First, through four separate ordinary least squares multiple regressions, we will regress consumption frequency of each type of meat (beef, pork, chicken, and fish) on gender, gender identity centrality, traditional gender role conformity, the interaction term for gender and gender identity centrality, and the interaction term for gender and traditional gender role conformity. We will follow up any significant interaction effect by testing the bivariate link between the significant moderating variable (i.e., centrality or conformity) and consumption within each gender level through a logistic regression. An effect is considered to be significant if it yields a p-value of less than .05.

Second, through two separate logistic multiple regressions, we will regress openness to going (1) vegetarian and (2) vegan on gender, gender identity centrality, traditional gender role conformity, the interaction term for gender and gender identity centrality, and the interaction term for gender and traditional gender role conformity. We will follow up a significant interaction effect by testing the bivariate link between the significant moderating variable (i.e., centrality or conformity) and openness within each gender level through a logistic regression. An effect is considered to be significant if it yields a p-value of less than .05.

Third, we will conduct six separate two-proportions z-tests to compare prospective reason for going vegetarian and vegan (including only the following three reasons: animals, health, and the environment) between men and women. Three tests will compare the proportions of men versus women who would go vegetarian for (1) animals, (2) health, and (3) the environment. Another three tests will compare these proportions for reason for going vegan. An effect is considered to be significant if it yields a p-value of less than .05.

Fourth, among men, we will conduct two separate one-way analyses of variance (ANOVAs) to test whether gender identity centrality and traditional gender role conformity vary depending on what reason one would have for going vegetarian (including only the following three reasons: animals, health, and the environment). In these ANOVAs, reason will be the grouping variable and centrality or conformity the outcome variable. If an ANOVA is significant (p < .05), then we will conduct all three possible pairwise comparisons within this ANOVA to test for differences between the three specific reasons, which we will evaluate at a Bonferroni-adjusted significance threshold of p = .017. We will conduct this same analysis procedure for prospective reason for going vegan.

Fifth, we will conduct the analysis procedure described in the paragraph above among women.

outliers.value: Participants will be excluded from analyses if they indicate that they are vegetarian/vegan, fail an attention check in the survey, report a non-binary gender identity status, or enter that they are either an unpermitted (<18 years) or an impossible (>117 years) age.

dependent.value:
Dependent variables include consumption frequencies of beef, pork, chicken, and fish), openness to going vegetarian and vegan, and prospective reason for going vegetarian and vegan.

Consumption frequency of each meat (beef, pork, chicken, and fish) will be assessed by its own question, which will follow the following structure, with “[type of meat]” serving as a placeholder for each of the four types of meat to be assessed: “How often do you eat [type of meat]?” with responses (and how they will be scored in parentheses; not shown to participants) including never (1), a few times per year (2), once per month (3), a few times per month (4), once per week (5), 2 to 3 days per week (6), 4 to 6 days per week (7), 1 meal per day (8), 2 meals per day (9), and 3 or more meals per day (10). For example, for beef, this question will read, “How often do you eat beef?”

Openness to going vegetarian will be assessed by the question, “Do you plan on becoming a vegetarian at any upcoming point in your life?” to which responses will include “no,” “maybe,” and “yes.” Participants who respond “no” will be classified as not open to going vegetarian, whereas participants who respond either “maybe” or “yes” will be classified as open to going vegetarian.

Openness to going vegan will be assessed in the same manner as openness to going vegetarian, but with the word “vegan” in place of “vegetarian.”

Prospective reason for going vegetarian will be assessed by the question, “If you were to ever become a vegetarian in the future, what would be your main reason for doing so?” to which response will include “for animals,” “health reasons,” “the environment,” “religion,” “taste preference,” “disgusted by meat,” “financial reasons,” “my friends/family are vegetarian,” “my significant other is vegetarian,” or “other (please specify).”

Prospective reason for going vegan will be assessed in the same manner as prospective reason for going vegetarian, but with the word “vegan” in place of “vegetarian,” and “meat / animal products” in place of “meat.”

Independent variables include gender, gender identity centrality, and traditional gender role conformity.

Gender will be assessed by the item, “Please select your gender,” with responses including “Man,” “Woman,” “Non-Binary,” and “Other.”

Gender identity centrality will be assessed by the following 4 items. Each item will read either “man” or “woman” depending on what participants indicate their own gender is. “I often think about the fact that I am a man/woman,” “Overall, being a man/woman has very little to do with how I feel about myself” (reverse-scored),” “In general, being a man/woman is an important part of my self-image,” and “The fact that I am a man/woman rarely enters my mind (reverse-scored).” Responses will range from 1 (strongly disagree) to 7 (strongly agree).

Traditional gender role conformity will be assessed by Kachel et al.’s (2016) traditional masculinity/femininity scale, which is comprised of the following 6 items: “I consider myself as…” “Ideally, I would like to be…” “Traditionally, my interests would be considered as…” “Traditionally, my attitudes and beliefs would be considered as…” “Traditionally, my behavior would be considered as…” and “Traditionally, my outer appearance would be considered as…” Responses will range from 1 (very feminine) to 7 (very masculine). This variable will be reverse-scored for women so that higher scores reflect greater conformity to gender roles for one’s own gender for all participants (i.e., higher femininity for women, higher masculinity for men).

conditions.value: There are no conditions in this survey; all participants will complete the same survey.

hypothesis.value: We will test whether gender identity centrality and/or traditional gender role conformity (i.e., degree of self-ascribed traditional masculinity over femininity for men and traditional femininity over masculinity for women) predict current level of meat consumption frequency (specifically, consumption of beef, pork, chicken, and fish) and openness to going vegetarian and vegan. We hypothesize that each of these variables’ links to meat consumption and openness will be moderated by participant gender. Specifically, we hypothesize that lower centrality and lower conformity will predict lower meat consumption and greater openness among men whereas higher centrality and higher conformity will predict lower meat consumption and greater openness among women. We will also test whether men and women would have different reasons for going vegetarian or vegan in the future, if they were to do so, setting no directional hypotheses for this set of tests. Lastly, we will test, within each gender, whether one’s main reason for going vegetarian or vegan in the future, if one were to do so, is associated with one’s levels of gender identity centrality and/or traditional gender role conformity. We set no directional hypotheses for this set of tests.

summary.value:
We aim to explore the internal structure of abstract and concrete construal and its nomological network. To this end, we will explore people’s reports on items representing abstract and concrete thoughts during an encounter with a challenging event. The items are chosen from a larger list of items based on a previous study and experts’ opinions.
We will explore the consistency between items (i.e., whether they reflect one bidirectional, or separate independent factors, or if there is a latent structure to this construct altogether), and their construct validity, by examining correlations with relevant individual difference measures listed in the attached document.
